results.title: Air at work
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
This program presents experiments that demonstrate the varying forces that are created when air moves. Demonstrates the theory of flight and the creation of weather patterns.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Video Arts

results.title: Mix a material
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham, Landmark Films and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Looks at why materials bend, stretch and break. Demonstrates experiments to show the behaviour of molecular lattices in everyday substances from chocolate to rubber ballons.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham, Landmark Films and Video Arts

results.title: The Invisible force
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Konrad, the kitchen robot, shows students that gravity and friction determine how everything on earth behaves during movement. Using simple experiments that can be reproduced in class or at home, he reveals the nature of the forces acting upon us.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films

results.title: Make a noise
results.creator_credit: Christopher Haws, Michael Latham and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Start Here: Adventures into Science”.
Explains what sound is and why some sounds are musical. Shows how to experiment with vibrations and to create music. This programme is suitable for upper primary science.

results.title: Farming the forest for woodchip
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film concentrates on the process involved in the production of woodchips in the Eden area of New South Wales, from tree-felling to the shipment of chips to Japan. The film stresses that the logged areas will rejuvenate naturally thus allowing continual use of the forest. For a more critical view of woodchipping see “The Vanishing forest”. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Far out kids animation
results.creator_credit: Anthony Lucas, Paul Williams, Peter Nicholson and Steve French
results.brief_description: The AFI put together this compilation of Australian animated films suitable for children under nine. It includes: “There’s Dragons” - a funny film about a silly dragon, “That’s Progress” - a young boy doing a school project on historic buildings is constantly thwarted by Mr Progress, who keeps demolishing the buildings to put up car parks, “The Lighthouse Made Three” a whimsical love story based on a popular song. “Thumpalong” about a king who hates music, and “DuDu and the Line”, a celebration of the wild and free flowing transformations available to the animator.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anthony Lucas, Paul Williams, Peter Nicholson and Steve French

results.title: Fantasy of feet
results.creator_credit: Frederic Goodich, Warren Brown and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows scenes of feet walking, dancing, running, and jumping, barefooted and in sandals, flippers, slippers and boots to encourage children to think about the different kinds of shoes and how feet serve their many functions. Suitable for upper primary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frederic Goodich, Warren Brown and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Fantasy man
results.creator_credit: John Meagher, Basil Appleby, Darrell Lass and Centaur Enterprises
results.brief_description: Mid-life crisis, bored with work, his wife and his life, Nick Bailey (Harold Hopkins) begins to fantasize about the young and rather attractive Donna (Kerry Mack), who works at the hamburger stand near his office. Nick’s wife Liz (Jeanie Drynan) confused and disturbed by Nick’s strange and secretive behaviour, especially his long showers, finds herself fantasizing about a former lover after a chance meeting. Can their marriage survive? Does anyone care? A low-budget film with a pretty ordinary plot. Cast also features Kate Fitzpatrick.

results.title: Fantasia 2000
results.creator_credit: Don Hahn, Eric Goldberg, Francis Glebas, Gaetan Brizzi, Hendel Butoy, James Algar, Paul Brizzi, Pixote Hunt, Donald W. Ernst and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Presented by Walt Disney’s nephew Roy E. Disney, “Fantasia 2000” is a realisation of Walt’s dream to reissue his marriage of music and animation that was “Fantasia” (1940). The brief introduction also covers Disney milestones in animation innovation. “Fantasia” was a grand experiment in film-making, a concert film and homage to animation. Stylistically speaking, it prescribed the use of Fantasound which included 64 speakers. Disney originally intended the film to be periodically re-released with the inclusion of new scenes; due to poor audience response and various other factors, this wish never eventuated - until now. Shot on Imax by seven directors (Pixote Hunt, Hendel Butoy, Eric Goldberg, James Algar, Francis Glebas, Gaetan and Paul Brizzi, Don Hahn), “Fantasia 2000” presents seven new segments and only one carry over scene from the original - Mickey Mouse in “The Sorcerer’s apprentice.” This new interpretation of music from composers such as Beethoven, Respighi, Gershwin, Shostakovich and Stavinsky received mixed reviews from critics who thought it did not match the continuity of style of the original or the substance. Steve Martin, Bette Midler, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury and Quincy Jones are just a few of the big names who introduce each segment. The Chicago Symphony Orchestra is conducted by James Levine.
